Award.AwardTitle: Imaging Morphology, Ion Conductance and Degradation Processes in Energy Materials on the Nanometer Scale Using Tunneling Atomic Force Microscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Number: 1608914 PI: Buratto, S.
Imaging Morphology, Ion Conductance and Degradation Processes in Energy Materials on the Nanometer Scale Using Tunneling Atomic Force Microscopy

Polymer electrolyte membranes (PEMs) are key components in electrochemical devices such as fuel cells and redox flow batteries. These devices are capable of producing clean energy with high efficiency and are useful in tandem with intermittent renewable electricity generation technologies using wind or solar when the wind or sun is not available and also to store electricity in the form of chemical energy for energy storage. PEMs are, in general, composed of a polymer with a hydrophobic backbone and side chains terminated with hydrophilic functional groups. When this polymer is cast in films to make the membrane, phase separation between the hydrophobic and hydrophilic segments results in a random nanoscale network of hydrophilic channels through which ions are transported and hydrophobic domains that give the membrane mechanical strength. Novel membrane chemistries are currently under development, especially alkaline electrolyte membranes, but require feedback from characterization efforts, especially on the nanometer scale, in order to understand ion conductance and its dependence on the pore network structure. Another key question is how the membrane degrades during operation and that impacts the performance of the device. This project addresses this need for fundamental understanding on how degradation occurs in these types of electrochemical devices. Knowledge gained will help to close the feedback loop between designing the membrane's structure and its resultant function. Students working on this research will learn about alternative power sources, help optimize membrane function, and provide valuable insight and inspiration into the development of the next-generation membrane materials.

This project leverages a suite of experimental methods that utilize tapping (or AC) mode atomic force microscopy (AFM) and conductive probe AFM (cAFM) to probe the pore connectivity and ion transport in proton-conducting membranes such as PEMs. The Principal Investigator and his research group have developed these techniques. In this project, the tools are adapted and applied to the study of alkaline electrolyte membranes, which transport hydroxide ions. Under alkaline conditions, the oxygen reduction half-reaction has significantly improved kinetics, obviating the need for precious metal catalysts. This project's transformative feature includes the characterization of PEM membrane morphology and hydroxide-ion conductance on the nanometer length scale to provide a link between morphology and conductance. The project also includes the investigation of the ion domain morphology and connectivity in vanadium redox flow batteries that utilize proton-conducting membranes under drastically different operating conditions than the alkaline fuel cells. These experiments probe the dependence of the pore network structure on the electrolyte concentration, the degree of vanadium ion penetration into the membrane and the prolonged exposure of the membrane surface to water and heat. The ultimate goal is fundamental understanding of ion conduction, in terms of the size and distribution of the chemical domains responsible for the transport in both alkaline fuel cells and vanadium flow cell batteries. In both systems, ion conductance will be studied systematically as a function of (1) the device operating conditions, (2) the membrane type, and (3) the degree of membrane degradation and decomposition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In research supported by this grant Prof. Steven K. Buratto of the University of California, Santa Barbara has utilized state-of-the-art atomic force microscopy (AFM) methods to image ion conductance and pore structure polymer electrolyte membranes on a nanometer length scale and at the level of a single conducting pore.  The polymer electrolyte membrane is the quintessential nanomaterial with hydrophilic pores on the order of 10 nm through which ions are transported.  Membrane materials are intricately designed and require equally intricate characterization, especially on the nanometer scale, in order to understand ion conductance and its dependence on the pore network structure.  Prof. Buratto and his research group have been able to adapt and extend their existing AFM methodology to the study of alkaline electrolyte membrane fuel cells that utilize drastically different membrane materials than their proton-conducting analogues.  The Buratto group has also investigated ion domain morphology and connectivity in vanadium redox flow batteries that utilize proton-conducting membranes in operando.

Several important innovations and discoveries have come from our work. We developed electrostatic force microscopy (EFM), to investigate the channel connectivity and ion conductance of ionomer membranes used in fuel cell and flow cell battery applications.  Initially, we focused our studies on Nafion® membranes, the prototypical proton-conducting membrane material.  EFM measurements were shown to be influenced by a capacitive force gradient and allowed us to map the excess surface charge and the local dielectric properties of the membrane films. Through careful modeling of the EFM data and correlation of tapping-mode AFM, it was possible to produce a model of the individual channels in Nafion®, even for channels that do not span the membrane (i.e. dead-end channels).

We adapted our AFM methods to investigate channel connectivity and conductance in novel anion exchange membrane (AEM) materials.  In this work, we collaborated with Prof. Bryan Coughlin of the Department of Polymer Science and Engineering at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.  The Coughlin group synthesized anion-conducting materials based on phosphonium-containing block copolymers.  Together our two groups investigated block copolymer AEMs that range from moderate to high ion exchange capacities (IECs). The Coughlin group showed previously that the IEC can manipulate the structure of the membranes from inverse hexagonally packed cylinders at moderate IEC to body-centered cubic spheres at high IEC.  In our collaborative work, we compared the surface and bulk morphology of the QP block copolymers using AFM, cross-sectional TEM, and small-angle x-ray scattering (SAXS). We found that at low IEC (AEM 13), hexagonally packed PIp cylinders align parallel to the surface while perpendicular through the bulk of the membrane. While at moderate IEC (AEM 16), the PIp cylinders align perpendicular throughout the bulk and surface of the membrane. At high IEC (AEM 19), we found a loosely ordered BCC packing of PIp spheres.  We have also adapted our electrostatic force microscopy (EFM) methods to investigate the connectivity of the ionic phase between the parallel aligned cylinders of AEM 13 and the perpendicular alignment of AEM 16. We have found a significant number of “dead-end” regions where charge was trapped at the surface in AEM 13. This can be attributed to the insulating PIp cylinders, which prevent charge from reaching the surface. AEM 16 on the other showed no dead-end regions and was entirely connected throughout the membrane.

We also investigated surface morphology and hydroxide conductance of a commercially available quaternary ammonium (QA) anion exchange membrane (AEM) by FumaTech (FAA-3). FAA-3 represents one of the few relatively high performance and chemically stable AEMs that is also commercially available.  We investigated FAA-3 in its bromide (FAA-3-Br-) and hydroxide form (FAA-3-OH-) under dehydrated and hydrated conditions and compared our results with previously published bulk scattering data. Under dehydrated conditions, both membranes showed no phase contrast indicating the absence of phase-separated hydrophilic domains at the surface. At hydrated conditions, FAA-3-Br- shows randomly dispersed isolated clusters while FAA-3-OH- shows elongated fibrillar structures extending microns in length. Conductive-probe AFM (Cp-AFM) of hydrated FAA-3-OH- showed that these elongated regions were insulating, which suggests that the structure of these regions have a QA-rich interior with a PPO shell. These results provide morphological evidence for the conduction of hydroxide at the surface and its dependence on hydration level.

Finally, we have designed and constructed a new AFM flow cell for imaging ionomer membranes in vanadium flow cell batteries under liquid flowing conditions.  The new flow cell yielded high quality AFM imaging of the Nafion surface under flowing conditions.  In addition, conductive AFM could be performed simultaneously with the AFM height and phase over the same area.  One-to-one correspondence between with the aqueous domains depicted in the AFM phase image with the current spikes in the cAFM image indicates that the current imaging is possible in this geometry.  This image represents one of the first operando images of an operating flow cell battery.
